Award.AwardTitle: Structural Metamaterials with Saint-Venant Edge Effect Reversal for Static Load Pattern Modification and Recognition

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research leading to a new class of mechanical metamaterials that, unlike the traditional materials, respond stronger to finer spatial fluctuations in loads than to coarser ones. The notion of metamaterials refers to an exciting class of material systems with engineered internal structure. Specially designed interactions among individual elements of the internal structure lead to a reversal of certain basic properties observed in natural materials. These new properties unveil practical opportunities that can be highly beneficial to the society. For example, photonic metamaterials may be used to fabricate ultrathin lenses for medical applications, and acoustic metamaterials can provide highly efficient sound insulation and earthquake hazard mitigation systems. They will also potentially enable in-situ identification of unsafe loading conditions in structures and building foundations. The paradigm changing aspects of this work will help to inspire undergraduate students and underrepresented groups to participate in the research activities through undergraduate research experiences and the submission of manuscripts in the ASEE Journal of Engineering Education.

This research will create a sufficient base of knowledge to enable design and fabrication of these novel metamaterials. The concept of deformation decay spectrum will be introduced on the basis of transfer matrix eigenanalysis of a discrete nonlocal elastic medium in the Fourier domain. Based on the decay spectrum and density of states analyses, phase diagrams will be constructed in the design space of interesting candidate structures to show what combinations of structural parameters are suitable for an actual metamaterial. Availability of asymptotic bandgaps in the decay spectrum will indicate that the metamaterial behavior is achievable for a given nonlocal medium. Mathematically, these bandgaps will require complex-valued decay parameters, as a nonlinear function of the Fourier mode index in a fundamental solution to the governing equation of equilibrium of the nonlocal medium. A complex decay parameter will point out on certain anomalies in the behavior of static Fourier modes in the material, including phase shift and inversion, and mode blockage at surfaces accompanied by the Saint-Venant edge effect reversal. These basic phenomena will be shown to create opportunities for static deformation cloaking, filtering and inversion. More broadly, they will lead to functional metamaterials for qualitative modification and recognition of surface load patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project reveals design principles of novel materials with unusual mechanical properties. These materials are a class of voided solids, such as foams or sponges, with an engineered repetitive internal architecture. Unlike any naturally occurring foams, they possess one special feature, which is the far-reaching mechanical interactions between a pair of nodal points in the material interior. Materials that demonstrate features beyond those seen in the natural systems are often called metamaterials, a word derived from Greek μετά – “beyond, after”.    

Engineering of the far-reaching interactions in the metamaterials demonstrated here generally provides opportunities to control mechanical deformation and in a user-preferred manner. Effective mechanical properties of these metamaterials are a function of the external load type. This means that such materials could deform under one type of mechanical loading, but remain intact in response to other types of loading, or redirect a concentrated load away from it its original axis. They could also maintain small details of their deformation at large distances away from the loads that create this deformation, and this phenomenon is known as the reverse Saint-Venant’s edge effect.

Practically, this research work paves the way toward a range of mechanical devices and components that could not be envisioned earlier. Examples include selective deformation blocking surfaces, load rectifiers and polarizers for hazard resilient civil infrastructure, and impact energy deflectors for body armor and military defense applications.

Research findings of this project could also facilitate advances in the adjacent fields of optics, acoustics, nondestructive testing of structures, 3D printing methods, and data science.
